newsitem.title: UK: Libya's new Murzuk oil field output at 50,000 bpd.
newsitem.headline: Libya's new Murzuk oil field output at 50,000 bpd.

text.p: Libya's giant Murzuk oil field is producing at a rate of about 50,000 barrels per day (bpd) and is on course to hit its target of 100,000 bpd by the end of 1997, industry sources said on Thursday.
The $1 billion project, operated by Spain's Repsol in partnership with Austria's OMV and France's Total SA, started producing last December at a rate of 20,000 bpd.
"The field is currently producing at about 50,000 bpd and is on course for 100,000 bpd by the end of this year," said a source familiar with the project.
The success of Murzuk and other new fields under development with foreign partners is vital to Libya's efforts to maintain crude oil production capacity at 1.4-1.5 million bpd.
Libya produced 1.43 million bpd in March, up 30,000 bpd from February, and above its OPEC quota of 1.39 million bpd, according to a recent Reuters survey of officials, industry monitors and analysts.
Murzuk production is currently flowing into Libya's Zawia refinery, with the foreign partners taking delivery of alternative export grades such as Es Sider in exchange.

Industry sources say Murzuk, a high quality light crude, is unlikely to appear on the Mediterranean spot market before the second quarter of 1998. Second phase production at Murzuk is expected to reach 200,000 bpd.
"The refinery can only take 100-120,000 bpd but before Murzuk can be exported the pipeline capacity needs to be expanded," said a source.
